text: coming up next is the science fiction radio show so stay with us this is the science fiction radio show a commentary on science fiction and fantasy and here are your hosts this is david carson and daryl lane sooner or later a true science fiction fan has to attend a convention conventions range from the incredible world con a world science fiction convention with thousands of people in attendance to small local gatherings with less than 100 fans and then there are the conventions in the middle big enough to attract first-rank authors and have a fascinating dealer's room but small enough to create a comfortable intimate atmosphere between guests and fans such a convention is aggie con a yearly science fiction gathering held in college station texas aggie con is organized and run by students at texas a&m university at the last aggie con number 14 held in the spring of 1983 we spoke with gordon lewis the head of the aggie con committee we asked him to give us a little of the background behind aggie con aggie con number one so far as i know was not originally called aggie con it was just called the science the texas a&m science fiction convention convention or something to that effect and they just decided it would be real fun to invite an author down and have a little miniature convention that lasted two days and i think they showed three films i saw a report on aggie con four i think aggie con three was the first one that was called aggie con i saw a report on number four they took in a total of eight hundred dollars and spent four hundred dollars and they had two guests and showed six films total and that was about all the programming they had and since then we have moved onward and upward to better and better things to where this year we have 30 guests we're showing eight major films at night we have uh film turning all day long and we have the panels and the readings and our budget this year is something like uh to take in 15 000 and to spend around 14 000 was what was budgeted putting on a major science fiction convention as aggie con certainly is takes a good deal of work the work is done by a committee on the texas a&m campus called cefid variable we asked lewis what the word cefid variable meant a cefid variable is a pulsating star which um there is one in the cephas star system and if you look at it it will appear to grow brighter and dimmer and occasionally to change colors and that's where we took our name from what does cefid variable actually do cefid variable is a science fiction and fantasy committee it's out of the student programs office here on campus and because we are a committee we do programming through the student programs office some of the other clubs on campus do their own activities and programming just for their own members but we program for the entire university as well as aggie con which is for people who aren't even members of the university is aggie con the only responsibility of cefid variable that's our major reason for being however we also program all year long we show science fiction fantasy films here on campus and we are a meeting place for science fiction fantasy fans here on campus also on occasion we do send delegates to other conventions within the state as well as outside the state usually in the summertime though because most of our students are busy during the fall and spring lewis says 95 percent of the members of cefid variable are students at the university but not all uh we have a few who are not most of them are like uh we have one former student we have one person who is laying out for a few semesters while he works and that way he can become a texas resident and not have to pay out of state tuition and uh becky matthews who is one of our guests we kind of count her as a member of the convention committee because she was chairman of aggie con 11 and uh has helped us with the roast program this year next time we'll talk with gordon lewis about the fascinating attractions aggie con has to offer this has been the science fiction radio show production of the permian basin science fiction association produced in conjunction with odessa college in odessa texas and i'll see you next time bye bye progress . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . We had a NASA presentation yesterday. We have had one of those for the past three years, and we consider that to be pretty regular at this convention. We're having a slideshow this afternoon on Don Punschatz's artwork, and we try to have an art slideshow, or at least we've been trying to, for the past three years. We have the two movie companies that are here, Disney and Columbia Pictures, that are promoting films, and I believe that since I've been here at AggieCon 12, I believe we didn't have any movie promotions, but at 11 and 13, and at this one, we have had movie promotions. We have trivia quizzes. We have the amateur art contest. We have the art auction, as well as other stuff that's auctioned off. This year we had the world premiere performance of Mr. Harry Harrison's play. That is a first, as far as I know. We also have the pro art gallery, where pro artists can display their work, and the fans can come and look at it. We have an autograph session, a guest reception. Plus, you can usually find the guests down in the party room, if they're not doing anything else. The authors at this year's AggieCon, the 14th, would have interested any science fiction fan. Harry Harrison was the guest of honor, and there was also a special guest, Stephen R. Donaldson. Harrison has written science fiction for a long time, and is known for such works as the Death World books, and for the stainless steel rat novels. And Donaldson is one of the hottest fantasy authors working today. His two Chronicles of Thomas Covenant series have sold in the millions. Lewis says that this year's AggieCon gave more emphasis to one aspect of science fiction and fantasy that many casual readers don't give much thought to. This year we have really tried to do more stuff for the artists than we ever have in the past. Usually we have like one panel, the amateur art contest, the auction, and that's about it. And this year we've programmed two panels on art. We again have the auction and the contest. We have more judges for the contest this year than we've had in the past. The artist guest of honor was Michael Whalen, who for the past two years running has been given the Nebula Award as the best science fiction fantasy artist of the year. Anyone who reads science fiction has seen Whelan's work. His paintings are found on the covers of many science fiction and fantasy books. One of his latest creations was on the dust jacket of Arthur C. Clarke's best-selling novel, 2010, Odyssey 2. We asked Lewis how AggieCon compared with other science fiction conventions in Texas. Well, we have been billed as the largest annual science fiction convention so far as attendance is concerned. Overall, I do believe that we have a larger attendance if you count both the one-day passes as well as the full convention passes than what other science fiction conventions have. A lot of that is probably due to the students here on campus. But we do bring in quite a few outside individuals. For instance, this year we had 60 non-student convention passes for the full convention that were sold in advance. That means before March 1st. We'll conclude our conversation with Gordon Lewis on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The mejor flaunt is now since 2020. fixing in seasons and the lease of the 시ther Universe ruling whereby Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is David Carson. And Daryl Lane. We are talking with Gordon Lewis, head of the Texas A&M Student Committee, which put on this year's successful AggieCon. And this year's AggieCon, the 14th, has to be considered a success. The guest of honor was science fiction author Harry Harrison, making one of his occasional trips to the United States from his home in Ireland. The special guest of honor was Stephen R. Donaldson. Probably no fantasy author since Tolkien has sold more books than Donaldson has. His Chronicles of Thomas Covenant 1 and 2 have sold in the millions. The activities at AggieCon 14 were numerous and fascinating. Fans could mingle with the authors and ask questions about their work, for one thing. And this opportunity would have to be the heart of any science fiction convention. But there was also a well-stocked dealer's room, movies 24 hours a day, panels, art shows, a masquerade. In other words, enough activity to give a fan a complete immersion in science fiction for almost four full days. We asked Gordon Lewis how they went about getting authors to be guests of AggieCon. Well, usually what we like to do is there are some authors here in Texas, as well as some artists, who are kind of like traditionalists at AggieCon. They've been coming for several years. We try and invite all of them, and usually most of them will come down here. So far as our major guests, we have the guest of honor, and we have a special guest. This year we were going to have co-guests of honor. We were going to have Ann McCaffrey as well as Harry Harrison, but Ann had to back out because of medical problems. Harry Harrison was then left as our only guest of honor, which in the past we've only had one. We have our special guest, like I said. We have a toastmaster. This year it's Dr. Chad Oliver from the University of Texas, and he will be presenting a program at the banquet this evening. He said he'd give us 15 minutes of wit and humor. Chad Oliver has been writing science fiction for over 30 years and has been a regular feature at AggieCon. Some of the other local authors attending AggieCon 14 were Howard Waldrop, Lee Kennedy, Ardeth Mehar, and George Proctor. The out-of-state writers included Ed Bryant and Bob Vardaman. We asked Louis what the biggest problem in planning AggieCon was. The fact that all of the officers are students, and we all have our homework here from the university, plus all of the paperwork that is required. And I think the only reason that was a real problem at this convention was because none of the paperwork was done when I took over in mid-October. I ended up having to do the majority of the paperwork, I and my officers, at that point. AggieCon is put together by a student committee at Texas A&M University known as Cefed Variable. We wondered if the students joined the committee because they were serious science fiction fans, or just for social reasons. Both, really. The majority of the people in there are really interested in science fiction. I, myself, am very interested in science fiction and fantasy. And it is a pretty nice social atmosphere also. The majority of the people in the committee are real good friends, and we get along real well. How many students from Cefed Variable work on the convention? We have, if I remember right, 16 officers. Eight of those have assistants. And we have probably ten of what we term gophers, which means general officer for everything ridiculous. Basically, they are the peons in the organization that go and do everything that the rest of us don't have time for. And then, so far as workers at the convention, just general committee members that worked, there are probably another ten to twenty of those. Lewis says the experience of putting on AggieCon is worthwhile, but... I would say that no one should criticize the way a science fiction fantasy convention is run until they've been on my end of the deal. Because until you have tried to set one of these things up, you really don't have any understanding as to what it takes to do so. All of the paperwork and all of the correspondence that has to be done, it really is a very big job, and I'm sure that this year I could not have done it without the help of all of my officers. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Fiction for 4.5 Quite well. Thank you. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane and David Carson. The science fiction of Dean Ng is always exciting and fast-paced, making it difficult for readers to put his books down. But his work also has messages to it, some information, some opinions that Ng wishes to communicate through the entertaining and exciting narrative. Anasazi, Systemic Shock, and Soft Targets are all good examples of exciting science fiction novels by Ng, which carry some messages or information along with a story. Ng bases his writing on ideas, which he's interested in at the time he writes. He tells us about some of his interests. There are a couple of themes that have occupied me a lot. I've been talking about 20 years ago when nobody else cared. Now, a lot of people care. And now I'm not interested in it much anymore because it's already been, not because of me, really, but for whatever reason, it has been taken up as an important issue. The second thing along that line would be survival, not only nuclear survival, but various other kinds. I write in survival publications. I design backpackers' wood stoves and all kinds of other gadgetry that would be very useful in survival contexts. I've had to make my own snowshoes to get out of the high Sierra one particular summer, which was hardly like a summer at all. It was a very late spring. But survival, and particularly the nuclear Holocaust survival issue, is one that I have dealt with for two or three years now. The End Ng's latest book is a good example of his method of writing about his immediate concerns. It's called Pulling Through, and it's based on the theme of survival. Pulling Through is a short novel on nuclear survival in the San Francisco Bay Area. And the short novel is followed in the same book by five articles, nonfiction articles, detailing some of the gadgetry and techniques that these people use to stay alive. So that it is not only a fast-paced, short novel, but it is also a manual of nuclear survival. Ng says he normally tries to proportion his stories between 90% entertainment and 10% information, but pulling through is a slight departure from that formula. That is a novel in which, oh, I must have 20% information in there and only 80% entertainment. But it is, again, extremely fast-paced. I set a nuclear survival scenario in the context of a great big overbearing and overwhelming bounty hunter in California. The kind of guy who, you know, goes around with weapons all the time and has a fairly high-tech environment. He's a man around whom things just happen, and they happen fast. But the book is probably 20% information. It's, I guess, the most thoroughly information-packed novel I've ever written. And the reviews that are just coming out are very nice reviews. So far, I haven't heard anybody complain that it's dull. Pulling Through is definitely not a dull novel. It's a fresh experiment in science fiction and one that will fascinate readers. We hope Ng continues to include information in his books, along with the narrative. That's really what science fiction is all about, anyhow. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show. So stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is David Carson. And Daryl Lane. Donald A. Waldheim has been involved in science fiction for over half a century. His influence has been, and still is, considerable. He was one of the original fans back in the 30s, and helped start the famous science fiction group, the Futurians, in New York in the late 1930s. He's written numerous novels and short stories. He's been an editor of science fiction for 40 years, and was responsible for the creation of the ace science fiction line. And today he's head of Dawes Science Fiction Books, the publishing house he founded in 1972. Obviously, Walheim knows science fiction inside and out. We asked him to comment on science fiction as a separate category of literature. Isn't that distinction between science fiction and other fiction, particularly mainstream, really an artificial one maintained by the publishing industry? Well, let me put it this way. It is an artificial category. All literature is literature. But, for the purposes of marketing, it is necessary to mark out the different genres or categories of what you might call standard reading. This derives from the fact of the old days of the pulp magazines, when a magazine was clearly marked a western, or a detective magazine, or a science fiction magazine. And because it knew that readers who bought that magazine knew what they were going to get. A mainstream is a very varied product. It consists of a story of books of modern adventure, books of future life, books of past life, books of historical, just experimental work. It can be anything. And your reader of category literature, which is actually, I think, the vast majority, know what they want. What they want is similar to what they have been reading. In other words, they don't really want to jump into something which is outside that which takes them into an escape. They are reading for escape reading. So you market science fiction because that's what they're looking for. You market a western if that's what they happen to like. If your western reader picks up something which is mainstream, he isn't going to like it. It doesn't give him what he's seeking. The same thing with romance novels. So you have to make it a category whether the writers like it or not. This is good for marketing. If you go into any bookshop, a large pay-the-back bookshop, you'll see that they do this. They put it in separate areas. They market science fiction. They market romance because they know that people are coming looking for that type of literature. A science fiction novel published as a mainstream work, unless it's marvelously good, very well advertised, it's going to be lost. It'll be forgotten. It won't even be seen. And it certainly won't be reviewed by the people who read science fiction. They won't tell each other. So for your own protection, for the author's protection, and for very sound economic reasons, you do have to list it as a category. Some people say that science fiction is treated as a second-class form of literature by critics, that it's unfairly neglected because it is a category literature. We asked Wolheim's opinion on that notion. Well, I am forced to agree with those people. The mainstream literature is, in a sense, regarded as the literature by, let's say, professors of English and by book critics. And things which are marked in a category style are looked down upon as hack writing. I see that happen, of course, living in New York. You see the New York Times book, which was probably one of the most snob organs in the country, in which they will never review science fiction books if they can help it. No matter what the critics think, if you like science fiction, you'll like what Donald A. Wolheim's Doll Books puts out. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show,

Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is David Carson.
And Daryl Lane.
We are talking with Gordon Lewis, head of the Texas A&M Student Committee, which put on this year's successful AggieCon.
And this year's AggieCon, the 14th, has to be considered a success.
The guest of honor was science fiction author Harry Harrison, making one of his occasional trips to the United States from his home in Ireland.
The special guest of honor was Stephen R. Donaldson.
Probably no fantasy author since Tolkien has sold more books than Donaldson has.
His Chronicles of Thomas Covenant 1 and 2 have sold in the millions.
The activities at AggieCon 14 were numerous and fascinating.
Fans could mingle with the authors and ask questions about their work, for one thing.
And this opportunity would have to be the heart of any science fiction convention.
But there was also a well-stocked dealer's room, movies 24 hours a day, panels, art shows, a masquerade.
In other words, enough activity to give a fan a complete immersion in science fiction for almost four full days.
We asked Gordon Lewis how they went about getting authors to be guests of AggieCon.
Well, usually what we like to do is there are some authors here in Texas, as well as some artists, who are kind of like traditionalists at AggieCon.
They've been coming for several years.
We try and invite all of them, and usually most of them will come down here.
So far as our major guests, we have the guest of honor, and we have a special guest.
This year we were going to have co-guests of honor.
We were going to have Ann McCaffrey as well as Harry Harrison, but Ann had to back out because of medical problems.
Harry Harrison was then left as our only guest of honor, which in the past we've only had one.
We have our special guest, like I said.
We have a toastmaster.
This year it's Dr. Chad Oliver from the University of Texas, and he will be presenting a program at the banquet this evening.
He said he'd give us 15 minutes of wit and humor.
Chad Oliver has been writing science fiction for over 30 years and has been a regular feature at AggieCon.
Some of the other local authors attending AggieCon 14 were Howard Waldrop, Lee Kennedy, Ardeth Mehar, and George Proctor.
The out-of-state writers included Ed Bryant and Bob Vardaman.
We asked Louis what the biggest problem in planning AggieCon was.
The fact that all of the officers are students, and we all have our homework here from the university, plus all of the paperwork that is required.
And I think the only reason that was a real problem at this convention was because none of the paperwork was done when I took over in mid-October.
I ended up having to do the majority of the paperwork, I and my officers, at that point.
AggieCon is put together by a student committee at Texas A&M University known as Cefed Variable.
We wondered if the students joined the committee because they were serious science fiction fans, or just for social reasons.
Both, really.
The majority of the people in there are really interested in science fiction.
I, myself, am very interested in science fiction and fantasy.
And it is a pretty nice social atmosphere also.
The majority of the people in the committee are real good friends, and we get along real well.
How many students from Cefed Variable work on the convention?
We have, if I remember right, 16 officers.
Eight of those have assistants.
And we have probably ten of what we term gophers, which means general officer for everything ridiculous.
Basically, they are the peons in the organization that go and do everything that the rest of us don't have time for.
And then, so far as workers at the convention, just general committee members that worked, there are probably another ten to twenty of those.
Lewis says the experience of putting on AggieCon is worthwhile, but...
I would say that no one should criticize the way a science fiction fantasy convention is run until they've been on my end of the deal.
Because until you have tried to set one of these things up, you really don't have any understanding as to what it takes to do so.
All of the paperwork and all of the correspondence that has to be done, it really is a very big job,
and I'm sure that this year I could not have done it without the help of all of my officers.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association,
produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.

Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Daryl Lane and David Carson.
The science fiction of Dean Ng is always exciting and fast-paced, making it difficult for readers to put his books down.
But his work also has messages to it, some information, some opinions that Ng wishes to communicate through the entertaining and exciting narrative.
Anasazi, Systemic Shock, and Soft Targets are all good examples of exciting science fiction novels by Ng, which carry some messages or information along with a story.
Ng bases his writing on ideas, which he's interested in at the time he writes.
He tells us about some of his interests.
There are a couple of themes that have occupied me a lot.
I've been talking about 20 years ago when nobody else cared.
Now, a lot of people care.
And now I'm not interested in it much anymore because it's already been, not because of me, really, but for whatever reason, it has been taken up as an important issue.
The second thing along that line would be survival, not only nuclear survival, but various other kinds.
I write in survival publications.
I design backpackers' wood stoves and all kinds of other gadgetry that would be very useful in survival contexts.
I've had to make my own snowshoes to get out of the high Sierra one particular summer, which was hardly like a summer at all.
It was a very late spring.
But survival, and particularly the nuclear Holocaust survival issue, is one that I have dealt with for two or three years now.
The End
Ng's latest book is a good example of his method of writing about his immediate concerns.
It's called Pulling Through, and it's based on the theme of survival.
Pulling Through is a short novel on nuclear survival in the San Francisco Bay Area.
And the short novel is followed in the same book by five articles, nonfiction articles, detailing some of the gadgetry and techniques that these people use to stay alive.
So that it is not only a fast-paced, short novel, but it is also a manual of nuclear survival.
Ng says he normally tries to proportion his stories between 90% entertainment and 10% information, but pulling through is a slight departure from that formula.
That is a novel in which, oh, I must have 20% information in there and only 80% entertainment.
But it is, again, extremely fast-paced.
I set a nuclear survival scenario in the context of a great big overbearing and overwhelming bounty hunter in California.
The kind of guy who, you know, goes around with weapons all the time and has a fairly high-tech environment.
He's a man around whom things just happen, and they happen fast.
But the book is probably 20% information.
It's, I guess, the most thoroughly information-packed novel I've ever written.
And the reviews that are just coming out are very nice reviews.
So far, I haven't heard anybody complain that it's dull.
Pulling Through is definitely not a dull novel.
It's a fresh experiment in science fiction and one that will fascinate readers.
We hope Ng continues to include information in his books, along with the narrative.
That's really what science fiction is all about, anyhow.

This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is David Carson.
And Daryl Lane.
Donald A. Waldheim has been involved in science fiction for over half a century.
His influence has been, and still is, considerable.
He was one of the original fans back in the 30s,
and helped start the famous science fiction group, the Futurians, in New York in the late 1930s.
He's written numerous novels and short stories.
He's been an editor of science fiction for 40 years,
and was responsible for the creation of the ace science fiction line.
And today he's head of Dawes Science Fiction Books, the publishing house he founded in 1972.
Obviously, Walheim knows science fiction inside and out.
We asked him to comment on science fiction as a separate category of literature.
Isn't that distinction between science fiction and other fiction, particularly mainstream,
really an artificial one maintained by the publishing industry?
Well, let me put it this way.
It is an artificial category.
All literature is literature.
But, for the purposes of marketing,
it is necessary to mark out the different genres or categories
of what you might call standard reading.
This derives from the fact of the old days of the pulp magazines,
when a magazine was clearly marked a western,
or a detective magazine,
or a science fiction magazine.
And because it knew that readers who bought that magazine
knew what they were going to get.
A mainstream is a very varied product.
It consists of a story of books of modern adventure,
books of future life,
books of past life,
books of historical,
just experimental work.
It can be anything.
And your reader of category literature,
which is actually, I think, the vast majority,
know what they want.
What they want is similar to what they have been reading.
In other words,
they don't really want to jump into something which is
outside that which takes them into an escape.
They are reading for escape reading.
So you market science fiction because that's what they're looking for.
You market a western if that's what they happen to like.
If your western reader picks up something which is mainstream,
he isn't going to like it.
It doesn't give him what he's seeking.
The same thing with romance novels.
So you have to make it a category whether the writers like it or not.
This is good for marketing.
If you go into any bookshop,
a large pay-the-back bookshop,
you'll see that they do this.
They put it in separate areas.
They market science fiction.
They market romance
because they know that people are coming looking for that type of literature.
A science fiction novel published as a mainstream work,
unless it's marvelously good,
very well advertised,
it's going to be lost.
It'll be forgotten.
It won't even be seen.
And it certainly won't be reviewed by the people who read science fiction.
They won't tell each other.
So for your own protection,
for the author's protection,
and for very sound economic reasons,
you do have to list it as a category.
Some people say that science fiction is treated
as a second-class form of literature by critics,
that it's unfairly neglected because it is a category literature.
We asked Wolheim's opinion on that notion.
Well, I am forced to agree with those people.
The mainstream literature
is, in a sense, regarded as the literature
by, let's say, professors of English
and by book critics.
And things which are marked in a category style
are looked down upon as hack writing.
I see that happen, of course, living in New York.
You see the New York Times book,
which was probably one of the most snob organs in the country,
in which they will never review science fiction books
if they can help it.
No matter what the critics think,
if you like science fiction,
you'll like what Donald A. Wolheim's Doll Books puts out.
